{{ArticleHistory |action1=WAR |action1date=22:06, 1 November 2016 (UTC) |action1link=Wikipedia:WikiProject Military history/Assessment/Mark XIV bomb sight |action1result=approved |action1oldid=747339181 }} {{WPMILHIST |class=A |A-Class=pass |b1=y|b2=y|b3=y|b4=y|b5=y|WWII=yes|Technology=yes|British=yes}} {{WPAVIATION|class=B|b1=y|b2=y|b3=y|b4=y|b5=y|Aircraft=yes}} {{dyktalk|21 November|2011|entry=... that the disastrous [[Battle_of_the_Heligoland_Bight_(1939)|Air Battle of Heligoland Bight]] in 1939 led to the development of the fast-acting computerized '''[[Mark XIV bomb sight]]'''?}}
==Not titled== > The task was contracted out to the Sperry Gyroscope Company, who re-engineering it to meet American standards,
What does this actually mean?[[User:BlaiseFEgan|Blaise]] ([[User talk:BlaiseFEgan|talk]]) 20:39, 5 January 2008 (UTC)
:It usually means that historically-different standard things like [[Screw_thread#History_of_standardization|screw threads]] are changed from UK ones ([[British Standard Whitworth|BSW]] or [[British standard fine thread|BSF]]) to US ones such as AF, etc. Also some dimensions may be changed slightly to allow use of different bar stock sizes, tolerances/clearances, etc. I've added a link in the article. [[User:Ian Dunster|Ian Dunster]] ([[User talk:Ian Dunster|talk]]) 09:49, 27 July 2008 (UTC)
::It's worth pointing out that such a conversion is not as simple as it might seem. As the "computor" is driven by mechanical motion of parts, any changes in those parts, even due to different sets of measuring units, can cause it to be wildly inaccurate. It was no mean feat for the UK and US versions to be built on separate drawings and still be 100% interchangeable! [[User:Maury Markowitz|Maury Markowitz]] ([[User talk:Maury Markowitz|talk]]) 12:12, 3 November 2011 (UTC)
== Air Publication AP 1730A ==
[http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/results/r?_q=Air+Publication+AP+1730A] Doesn't look like a published source. [[User:Keith-264|Keith-264]] ([[User talk:Keith-264|talk]]) 23:51, 7 November 2016 (UTC)
